Award.AwardTitle: Black Males in Middle School (HBCU-DCL EAGER): Investigating How STEM Mentoring Programs and Experiences Influences Their Academic and Career Interest in Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nationally, there is increasing interest in broadening the participation of minority males in engineering and other STEM-related fields. Compared to White and Asian males, many minority males are underrepresented in engineering. Throughout the theoretical and scientific literature, there is a dearth of research focused on minority males in engineering, especially on Black male students who have participated in engineering or other STEM-related mentoring programs and experiences. There are also very little scientific and popular literature that examines, specifically, how such programs may impact Black male middle school-aged students' academic and career interest in engineering. This research project is both timely and important to the National Science Foundation as well as other U. S. governmental agencies that are working to diversify the engineering workforce throughout the country.

Comprising quantitative and qualitative research methods,investigators from Bowie State University and Morgan State University outlined a comprehensive exploratory, mixed-method study that aims to pinpoint the different factors that shape Black middle school-aged students' interest in engineering and determine what specific experiences actually influence their understanding of engineering and other STEM-related fields. It is quite likely that the research findings will offer important insights on middle school-aged, Black males and how engineering and other STEM-related programs and experiences can influence their academic interests and career aspirations. Further, secondary and postsecondary professionals will be able to use the project findings to improve formal and informal engineering and other STEM-related learning experiences for Black middle school-aged students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF research project examined Black middle school boys’ experiences in out-of-school in engineering and technology at four Historically Black Colleges and Universities research sites. The study directly investigated the pedagogy, mentoring, and program structures that helped Black boys understand and develop an interest in engineering and technology content, concepts, coursework, majors, and careers, and develop positive self-efficacy, self-perceptions, and interest in this field of study. Diverse STEM college professors and Black STEM and non-STEM collegians taught and mentored Black boys in the program. The program's primary mentors were Black male STEM majors who taught, assisted with instruction, and mentored the Black male middle school students.

This mixed-methods study found that culturally responsive pedagogy and transactional instructional strategies were the most significant used. The instructors' and mentors' personal experiences also played a significant role in connecting with their students. The Black male mentors and instructors recognized the importance of getting to know, relating to, and building caring relationships with each of the Black boys. They also acknowledge that the boys are not the same and needed to get to know them individually and personally. The mentors and instructors used a variety of approaches to get  to know the boys (e.g., who they are, what they like, name, birthday, etc.), show them that they share similar interests (e.g., movies, sports, games, music, etc.), and personal experiences. Black male college students were more likely to use culturally responsive practices to build relationships, teach, assist, and mentor Black boys. Black men were more likely to use culturally responsive mentoring and instructional strategies intertwined with teaching STEM content and concepts and encourage them to pursue majors, take courses, and pursue careers.

The culturally responsive instructional strategies used were based on the instructors' knowledge of students and content. They used their students' interest in video games and consoles to teach them coding, 3D design, STEM concepts. The programs support Black boys in learning STEM concepts by being patient with them, provide individual/group help with challenging or misunderstood STEM concepts, and positive encouragement and feedback. The participants indicated that their teachers did not provide these supports, and the environment was not a safe learning environment at their school. Many of the young men did not have technology and engineering courses at their school. The students got to use Spheros, Tinkercad, 3D printers, drones, and/or robots technology as a part of their learning experience and participate in hands-on activities.

The transactional instructional strategies were meaningful learning, learning community, teacher-student relationship quality (TSRQ), and critical thinking to help the researchers better understand Black boys' perceptions of teacher's instructional practices, classroom climate, and personal attitudes/dispositions toward instruction. The higher students rated their perceived presence of meaningful learning, the higher was their rating of teacher-student relationship quality. The higher students rated their perceived learning connections, the greater observed learning community indicators. The higher the teacher-student relationship quality, the higher the observed learning community contexts. The more teachers and mentors used critical thinking factors, the increased the use of transactional pedagogical practices (meaningful learning, TSRQ, and learning community) in the out of school STEM program. The three transactional instructional strategies yield to students' perceived critical thinking in the STEM learning context.

The program mentoring structure varied at each research site. Overall, the project directors intentionally sought to recruit Black male college students to serve as mentors for Black boys. They also sought STEM majors but allowed non-STEM majors to serve as mentors at some sites. Most of the sites had Black male college students serve as mentors for the Black boys. Some of the programs had Black women serve as mentors too. One site had instructors do the dual role of instructors and mentors. Regardless of the mentoring structure, the students developed meaningful relationships with their mentors that they appreciated and benefited from. The Black male college mentors played a significant role in helping the participants learn STEM concepts, developing healthy racial, gender, and STEM identities, and more in-depth insight into being a Black male college student in a STEM discipline. Many of the participants started the programs with high interests in STEM and perceptions of their ability, but they did not possess insider knowledge of STEM content and technology, and what it means to engage in STEM. The program provided Black male participants with insider knowledge of STEM concepts, careers, and majors. Many of the Black boys planned to major in a STEM field and pursue a STEM career.

The programs helped the Black male students develop positive self-efficacy, self-perceptions, and interest in STEM. Many of the students possessed positive self-efficacy and self-perceptions of their ability to do STEM by participating in the program. Students who participated in the program for multiple years appeared to be more confident in their STEM knowledge and abilities.
